Now, the check for containing all three digits can be done by converting i to a string and checking for presence of each character. In Fortran:

function has_all_digits(i) result(res)

   integer, intent(in) :: i

   logical :: res

   character(len=20) :: s

   write(s, '(i0)') i

   s = adjustl(s)

   res = contains_char(s, '3') .and. contains_char(s, '5') .and. contains_char(s, '7')

end function

contains_char is a helper function:

logical function contains_char(s, c)

   character(len=*), intent(in) :: s

   character(len=1), intent(in) :: c

function has_all_digits(i) result(res)

   integer, intent(in) :: i

   logical :: res

   character(len=20) :: s

   write(s, '(i0)') i

   s = adjustl(s)

   res = contains_char(s, '3') .and. contains_char(s, '5') .and. contains_char(s, '7')

end function

logical function contains_char(s, c)

   character(len=*), intent(in) :: s

   character(len=1), intent(in) :: c

   contains_char = index(s, c) /= 0

end function

program main

   implicit none

   integer :: n, i, j, r, c, next_i, N

   integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: a, b

   ! Read input

   read*, n

   allocate(a(n))

   read*, a

   ! Compute r as XOR of all a elements

   r = 0

   do i = 1, n

      r = ieor(r, a(i))

   end do

   ! Compute array b

   allocate(b(n))

   do i = 1, n

      b(i) = ieor(r, a(i))

   end do

   ! Get N as first element of b

   N = b(1)

   ! Now process the second part

   c = 0

   i = 357

   do while (i <= N)

      if (has_all_digits(i)) then

         c = c +1

      end if

      ! Compute next_i

      i = next_i(i)

   end do

   print*, c

contains

   logical function has_all_digits(num)

      integer, intent(in) :: num

      character(len=20) :: s

      write(s, '(i0)') num

      s = adjustl(s)

      has_all_digits = (index(s, '3') > 0) .and. (index(s, '5') > 0) .and. (index(s, '7') > 0)

   end function

   integer function next_i(current_i)

      integer, intent(in) :: current_i

      character(len=20) :: s, new_str, reversed_str

      logical :: f

      integer :: len_s, j

      write(s, '(i0)') current_i

      s = adjustl(s)

      len_s = len_trim(s)

      new_str = ''

      f = .false.

      do j = len_s, 1, -1

         character(len=1) :: c = s(j:j)

         if (.not. f) then

            if (c == '3') then

               new_str = new_str // '5'

               f = .true.

            else if (c == '5') then

               new_str = new_str // '7'

               f = .true.

            else if (c == '7') then

               new_str = new_str // '3'

            else

               ! invalid digit, treat as 3?

               new_str = new_str // '3'

            end if

         else

            new_str = new_str // c

         end if

      end do

      if (.not. f) then

         new_str = new_str // '3'

      end if

      ! Reverse new_str to get the next number's string

      reversed_str = ''

      do j = len(new_str), 1, -1

         reversed_str = reversed_str // new_str(j:j)

      end do

      read(reversed_str, '(i0)') next_i

   end function

end program main
